section.title: Problem Solving 4 -- Multi-Step Problems and Leverage Variables
section.p: Some problems require you to calculate one or more intermediate values before solving the problem at hand. Sometimes the equation of value in these problems is actually a system of equations, other times you can write one equation and eliminate some unknowns. There is often one value which, while not the answer, is critical to solving the problem. I call this the leverage variable.

assemblage.title: 🧮 Calculator Tip:
assemblage.p: Sometimes you can solve for the leverage variable in the financial calculator, assign it to a different TMV category, re-enter the rest of the TMV data, and solve for the value that is called for in the problem.

introduction.p: 10,000 can be invested under two options:
OPTION 1: Deposit the 10,000 into a fund earning an effective annual rate of \iota; or
OPTION 2: Purchase an annuity-immediate with 24 level annual payments at an effective annual rate of 10%. The payments are deposited into a fund earning an effective annual rate of 5%.
Both options produce the same accumulated value at the end of 24 years. Calculate \iota.

task.p: Start with the endgame of the problem: what equation do you need to solve in order to solve the problem?
What value do you need to solve your equation? This is the leverage variable.
What information in the problem will help you find the value of the leverage variable? Use that information to set up an equation for the leverage variable.

Use your observation about elimination to solve this system (round answers to the nearest whole number, for simplicity).

statement.p: Dottie receives payments of X at the end of each year for n years. The present value of her annuity is 493. Sam receives payments of 3X at the end of each year for 2n years. The present value of his annuity is 2748. Both present values are calculated at the same effective annual interest rate. Determine v^n.
How might you know when you need to solve for a leverage variable before solving a given problem?
